caption: Interesting house, furnished as of 19th century. It feels like to walk in a house where the owner stepped out for a couple of minutes.... Worth a visit if you are in the neighbourhood.
Original

A place that deserves more frequentation because it feels good there. Basically it is a gardener's house who was lucky enough to meet a (great) man of the caliber of those who strengthened the Republic and who made us live like this today. On a practical level, it's very close to the train station and easy to find. 3 things to do: 1) immediately rename the place “Maison Gambetta”, you will double the number of visitors. Maison des Jardies, magnificent name, doesn't mean anything to anyone (and that's a shame). Sad reality: beautiful novels with bad titles are not read. 2) put one or two benches in the green space behind the statue. It's the kind of place that makes you want to read or "sit down" and that would have made me come back, 3) more difficult, move the tenant upstairs who lives at Gambetta's all the same! And show you around this little winter garden as well as its terrace (little café there, why not?) But rest assured, I already know that all this is and will remain on the order of the impossible. In any case, thank you for this dive into his life; there are some who know how to shape their destiny.
Family visit. Pretty house with a guide, I don't know if it's always the same, very interesting, which makes the visit even more fun. THANKS

Interesting visit to this little-known place which is nevertheless full of history. The 2:30 p.m. guided tour was really a plus to understand everything. On top of that, the guide was really pleasant to listen to.

This house of the illustrious is worth a visit....and it is worth following a guided tour...A dive into the life of Balzac and especially Gambetta....you are just a stone's throw from a pedestrian entrance to the Parc de St Cloud. Easy accessibility by transilien and/or bus....

Very interesting this small bucolic house in the gardens in Sèvres, which hosted 2 famous guests for 4 years, Balzac and Gambetta. I recommend the guided tour, led by a very lively young woman. And just a stone's throw away, the immense Sèvres Park, the timeless and verdant Sèvres and Ville-d'Avray with its superb Corot Ponds.

La Maison des Jardies, or Maison des Illustres, is a residence located in Sèvres in Hauts-de-Seine. First a winegrowers' house then transformed into a country house for Parisians looking to return to nature. Balzac settled in a neighboring chalet from 1838 to 1840. Removed from power, Gambetta occupied it until 1878 when he died there at only 44 years old. This "secular saint" is the subject of an annual pilgrimage by the Government but also many foreigners. Cute, comfortable little house with a pretty garden. I recommend the guided tour. Charming, friendly guide. Knows his subject well.

This little house where Balzac and Gambetta lived, who died there, is really worth the visit. Especially by the very pleasant guide who takes care to introduce us to these 2 men. Too bad it's not visited anymore. 25 minutes from La Défense and 5 minutes walk from Sèvres Ville d'Avray station.

This visit would not have been the same without the guided tour given by Mégane... She tells us the history of these places with fluidity and makes us want to listen to her... I loved it... Thank you a lot

A place full of history and stories, from Balzac to Gambetta. We had the chance to participate in a wonderfully organized escape game, ideal for my 9-year-old son, who came back rich in experience and with new knowledge. Thank you again and see you next year for a new adventure I hope!!
There will be a guided tour at 2:30 in the afternoon, which will last about an hour.

House that once belonged to Balzac where he wrote some of his masterpieces then sold the house following money problems. Léon Gambetta bought the house in 1878 and died here on December 31, 1882. Please note the house is not open every day and opted for the guided tour preferably. The Sèvres-Ville d'Avray train station is a 5-minute walk away.
A very nice surprise. A very interesting visit with an extraordinary guide!
Very interesting to visit. One of the homes of Honoré de Balzac and the last home of Gambetta. We discovered this not very well known place.

Friendly and charming. Free visit in 45 minutes maximum (if you read the signs, otherwise 20 minutes) because it is small. The house would benefit from being restored (cracks...). I will go back in the spring. Parking in the surrounding streets is free but few spaces, difficult with the car, it is better to go there by public transport.
The guided tour was very nice. We learn a lot about the political and personal life of Léon Gambetta and if we wish we can ask for more information on the trinkets that decorate the house.

Evocation of the 2 famous occupants of this house: successively Honoré de Balzac (1 room) then Léon Gambetta (the entire house). The guided tour is pleasant and lasts approximately 1 hour. The large statue on the upstream side of the house is due to Bartholdi, upon subscription from Alsatians and Lorrainers.

Little-known place that is worth the detour. Free the first Sunday of the month. Please note, the house is only open on Thursday/Friday and every other weekend. Visits are at 2:30 p.m., 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. (€6 full price, free under 26s). You absolutely must take the guided tour, the person who takes care of it is someone who is passionate about the history of the place and it is very interesting. This house was originally that of Balzac's gardener who lived next door and then it was Gambetta's last home. The neighborhood, very green, is sublime, plan more time to stroll there. Saint Cloud Park is a 5-minute walk away.

Open at 2:30 p.m., 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. This means that you must be in front of the door at one of these three times because it is time for a guided tour visit. Only one person to do the guide and checkout required!  Little known national monument, but worth the detour. Very well served (station nearby) Guided tour mainly focused on Léon Gambetta and part on Balzac.  I recommend because the guide is very nice, gives a lot of details and is available for any questions.

Small house full of objects that belonged to Gambetta. Portraits, caricatures, bronzes, photos, newspapers... his room, letters... an imposing monument to his memory. A pleasant and professional welcome. A guide with real knowledge about Balzac and Gambetta. A very nice visit. Please note visits at specific times only. 2:30 p.m., 4:00 p.m.... very low prices. The small problem is parking but we manage. A somewhat neglected garden, too bad.

This beautiful residence, on the outskirts of Paris, near the Saint Cloud park, was occupied in turn by Balzac in 1837, then purchased by Léon Gambetta where he died and very quickly became a place of memory. Although modest, and refurnished with furniture lent by the Mobilier National, it gives an unusual vision of these great men, including Gambetta, of whom it also houses a monument where his heart was before it was transported to the Pantheon during a huge parade. The visit can be combined with that of the nearby Saint Cloud park, perfect for eating and relaxing in the fresh air.

As of October 30, 2019, the dates and times that are open to the public are limited to the following, so please be careful when visiting.  Pendant quelques mois, la Maison des jardies est fermée et sera ouverte au public aux dates suivantes en visites-commentées : - mercredi 13/11/2019 à 15h -mercredi 27/11/2019 à 15h - mercredi 11/12/2019 à 15h - mercredi 8/01/2020 à 15h - mercredi 22/01/2020 à 16h
Pleasant visit with a passionate guide. We learned a lot. The places are nicely maintained and the atmosphere transports us back in time!
I love this little-known place and what's more, it has an extraordinary guide on site. Unfortunately I don't know her name but she is the one who does the visits. To do even with children.

Very good surprise, with a very friendly guide. Be careful, however, to choose the day and time carefully. If you are making the trip, I think it is essential to call a few days in advance to make sure it is open.
Superb experience for “child’s play monument” days. An acting troupe brought the place to life, the children loved it! THANKS!
Beautiful visit which reminds us of a page of French history. Thank you very much to the speaker who has a lot of humor.
House remained in its original state. Interesting and moving visit. The “behind the scenes” of the Bartholdi monument are worth seeing.
Very popular visit with our group of hikers. To do absolutely. We were very well received and the guide delighted us. THANKS.
To know a little more lived, Leoni Gambetra.
A mythical place where Balzac and Gambetta lived. A very good quality of welcome. Don't miss out on visiting it.
Discovery of a neighborhood frequented by famous people, Balzac, Gambetta. Well-preserved house, passionate guide.
Very beautiful, exotic visit that reminds us of life in the 19th century!
Very well preserved house, in its 19th century condition and mini-museum style. Great historical interest.
Very interesting. Guided tour by appointment only. Very comprehensive commentary from the guide
Very pleasant place which allows you to get to know Gambetta well. Good welcome.
Thanks to an excellent guide I rediscovered Gambetta thank you for this history lesson
